awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Improvement Award: A Geoarchaeological Investigation of Coastal Resources
awd_abstract_narration:
The goal of this dissertation project is to understand how changes in resource densities and distribution across landscapes impacted subsistence strategies, mobility, and social connectivity of foraging communities. Researchers previously noted that large-scale environmental shifts impacted floral and faunal communities, which likely influenced human social organization by changing resource distributions and the distances between them. Coastal communities are particularly sensitive to such shifts, as environmental changes may submerge or expose large sections of land. An archaeological investigation can address such considerations as the extended timescales capture repeated restructuring of resource distribution and density. Within this broader context, this project  considers the impacts of coastal shifts on nutrient-rich resources, and asks whether foraging communities responded by expanding or contracting their social networks. 

This research addresses larger questions about human response to changing resource distributions.  The doctoral student plans to use materials collected from coastal archaeological sites along a modern coastline and one in the hinterland, to better assess how forager subsistence strategies, mobility, and social connectivity were impacted across time and space. Previous research demonstrated that this area was subjected to multiple climatic events where the coastline expanded and contracted, offering a unique ability to situate these materials within a broader context. This project uses ostrich eggs to inform multiple dimensions of forager life: subsistence (eggs as food), technology (eggs as water containers), and social connections (flasks and beads as trade items). Investigators plan to analyze the eggshell surfaces, chemistry, and organic components, and present a model for using ostrich eggshell fragments more broadly to tackle questions of subsistence and mobility. By examining how foragers used ostrich eggs, a better understanding of responses to changes in resource distributions can be determined, as can an assessment of how this response changed over multiple climate cycles that had clear impacts on coastline resources.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences
org_div_long_name: Division of Behavioral and Cognitive Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Our objectives were to gain insights into how ancient hunter-gatherer communities along the South African coastline found food, traded goods, and coped with environmental changes over the last ~90,000 years. This period of time covers several Ice Age cycles, during which global sea levels were lower than today and the coastline was far from the sites. The alternating exposure and submersion of large swaths of land off the southern coastline of South Africa would have likely triggered a reorganization of the animal and plant communities, thus impacting the foraging community’s social organization, what foods were available, and how far and fast they moved to find it.

For this study, we used the potential for ostrich eggshell (OES) fragments from archaeological sites to illuminate these issues. OES are frequently recovered in African archaeological deposits, but their information potential has historically been overlooked. OES represent the remains of multiple dimensions of human behavior, including subsistence (nutrition, cooking), technology (eggs as containers such as flasks), and social interactions (manufacture into beads, engraved containers, trade and exchange). As this is a relatively new area of research, we also conducted experimental research on modern OES to provide a framework for separating human use of the eggs from other natural processes that may have affected them at the sites.

The co-PI collected data from ostrich eggshell fragments recovered from four archaeological deposits in South Africa. These sites represent both the coastal and hinterland landscape and ecology, and collectively contain sequences spanning multiple Ice Age cycles. She collected data on how the OES was broken, burned, modified by humans and carnivores, and affected by variables such as soil acid and being crushed/stepped on. The surface modifications were recorded with photography and high-resolution silicone casts, and 3D scans were produced at Yale University for statistical analyses.

The results of this project demonstrate that a rigorous analysis of how OES is altered provides insight into how archaeological sites are formed through both human behavior and natural processes. Our experimental research offers a method for understanding container manufacture and use. We show how processes such as heating in campfires and burial in the sediments can remove residues of natural paints (ochres) that may have been applies by ancient people to ostrich eggshell surfaces. Our results on repeated campfire/hearth use of the eggshell demonstrate that repeated heating can produce an exaggerated effect on eggshell color, which changes according to temperature exposure. Repeated exposures at specific temperatures produce a color that is consistent with higher temperatures, while repeated exposures at other temperatures have no effect. Finally, ongoing research on the surface modifications of experimental ostrich egg containers/flasks highlights how their surfaces change in a way that may make it possible to identify flask use from small archaeological fragments.

Results from the OES from Pinnacle Point, a site along the South African coast, showcase changes in how intensely the site was occupied during a time known as the Middle Stone Age. Through asessment of the characteristics of ~2000 fragments of archaeological OES, our results suggest that when the site was intensively occupied, more eggs were brought to it, processed, and burned. Increasing numbers of eggs were brought to site when the coastline was distant and coastal resources would have been harder to find. However, foragers continued to collect and transport eggs to the site despite the encroaching coastline. These results agree with analysis of other kind of archaeological materials that demonstrate increasingly intensive occupation after ~74,000 years ago.

This project provided training for community members of Mosselbay, South Africa, graduate students at the University of Cape Town, and undergraduate students from Yale University. This training offered participants practical experience with archaeology data collection and management, and skills in methods with numerous possible applications in archaeology, and transferrable methods in other fields that require data collection and analysis. Results have been shared at two academic conferences, including one in South Africa where fieldwork for this study took place. We have one paper in review and two others in preparation. Additionally, the methodology and framework for this study was shared with the academic communities at the Universities of Pretoria and Cape Town during fieldwork. It contributed to curation for all assemblages involved, and generated an archeive of photographs, silicone casts, and 3D scans of many specimens for future analysis.

 


Last Modified: 12/09/2024
Modified by: Hannah M Keller
